text.p: Malaysia's Tan Chong Motor Holdings Bhd has undertaken a major restructuring exercise to streamline its operations and give investors a direct stake in its various units, its managing director said on Friday.
"You have to restructure to look at new ways of doing things. You must be continuously improving," Tan Eng Soon told Reuters in an interview.
Under the proposed restructuring, the asset-rich firm will spin off its auto parts, non-motor and foreign operations divisions, retaining only the Malaysian motor unit.

The Malaysian auto parts division will be spun off as APM Holdings Bhd and the non-motor business as TC Corp Bhd. The overseas operations, which sell Nissan cars and own properties, will be spun off as Tan Chong International Ltd.
APM Holdings and TC Corp are to be listed on the Kuala Lumpur exchange and Tan Chong International on the Hong Kong bourse.
"We are giving shareholders a direct participation in the operating units...the business now is quite widespread," Tan said.
"If you like the Malaysia operations but not the others, now you can't sell. So I give you an option (with the demerger)."
Tan Chong Motor assembles and sells the vehicles of Japanese firm Nissan in Malaysia, Singapore and Hong Kong. It sells Nissan and Subaru vehicles in Singapore and Hong Kong.
In Malaysia, it produces about 2,000 vehicles a month.
The company also manufactures vehicle parts and is involved in property, and the trading of industrial equipment to Shiseido cosmetics.
Tan said he expects to get regulatory approval to split the operations later in the year and hopes to list the three units by the year's end.
Analysts said the restructuring would help to unleash the value of the various divisions, especially APM Holdings, one of Malaysia's largest automotive component manufacturers.

"I think the restructuring is good for shareholders because the earnings of Tan Chong Motor are not going anywhere," said MBf Northern Securities analyst Azizah Ahmad. "By splitting them up, APM (Holdings) valuation will be higher," she added.
The company posted net earnings of 259.8 million ringgit ($103.9 million) for the year ended December 31, 1996, a sharp gain over 1995's 135.2 million.

Company officials said they plan to double output of the firm's three popular Nissan vehicles in Malaysia to a total of 1,400 units a month by the end of this year. The models, which were launched last year, were the Nissan Cefiro saloon, the Serena and the Terrano four-wheel drive.
